questions.text: 1. A 32-year-old female presents to the emergency department with widespread blistering of the skin and mucous membranes after starting phenytoin for her epilepsy. On examination, there are extensive areas of epidermal detachment covering more than 30% of her BSA. What is the most appropriate initial management for this patient?
questions.solution:
This is a case of toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN), and the most appropriate initial management for this patient is the immediate discontinuation of phenytoin. This crucial step addresses the underlying cause of her severe skin reaction, preventing further progression of the condition.

Stevens-Johnson syndrome(SJS) is a drug-induced condition characterized by widespread epithelial keratinocyte necrosis of both skin and mucous membranes. It is due to cytotoxic T-lymphocytes. SJS with extensive involvement of skin (more than 30% of body surface area) is considered TEN.

The most common drugs involved in SJS/TEN are allopurinol, carbamazepine, lamotrigine, nevirapine, oxicam, nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs, phenobarbital, phenytoin, sulfamethoxazole, and sulfasalazine. 

Patients usually present 7-10 days after consuming the drug with malaise and fever. It then progresses to a skin rash starting on the face and chest, which then spreads over the rest of the body. There are purpuric macules that can easily be desquamated. Positive Nikolsky's sign may be present (gentle lateral pressure causing sliding of the epidermis).

SJS/TEN is classified based on the extent of epidermal involvement: 

* SJS: Epidermal detachment of less than 10% BSA with widespread purpuric macules or flat atypical targets

* SJS/TEN overlap: Epidermal detachment of 10-30% BSA with widespread purpuric macules or flat atypical targets

* TEN with spots: Epidermal detachment of >30% BSA with widespread purpuric macules or flat atypical targets

* TEN without spots: Epidermal detachment of >30% BSA with loss of large epidermal sheets without widespread purpuric macules or flat atypical targets

Septicaemia is a common life-threatening complication. The exposed dermis can act as a substrate for microbial colonization by organisms like S.aureus and P.aeruginosa, which can lead to systemic sepsis and multi-organ failure. Other complications include hypothermia, anaemia, fluid loss, and hypoalbuminemia. 

The first step in management is to identify and stop the offending drug. Those with extensive loss of epidermis should be admitted to the burns unit for skin-directed therapy, fluid replacement, and nutrition. The skin should be carefully handled to avoid further removal of the skin. In addition, local therapy should be provided for the eyes, mouth, and urogenital tract. Patients should be given analgesia and monitored for infection. Immunomodulating drugs like corticosteroids and cyclosporin may be used.

Pearl PM1948: Erythema multiforme vs. Stevens-Johnson syndrome/Toxic epidermal necrolysis

 

  Erythema multiforme major Stevens-Johnsons Syndrome Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis (Lyell syndrome)
% Body Surface-area

<10%

 <10% >30%
Causes Herpes simplex> Mycoplasma infection Drug induced e.g. cephalosporins, sulfa drugs, allopurinol Drug induced e.g. cephalosporins, sulfa drugs, allopurinol
Associated Symptoms Less fever and other constitutional symptoms Fever, malaise and headache Fever, malaise and headache
Mucosal Lesions Milder mucosal lesions Severe mucosal involvement Severe mucosal involvement
Lesions Erythematous papules, Target lesions, raised atypical target lesions, occasional bullous lesions

Vesicles on erythematous base, erosions, purpuric macules, Flat atypical target lesions

Nikolsky Sign Positive

Diffuse, generalized epidermal detachment

TEN with spots - with widespread purpuric macules and flat atypical target lesions

TEN without spots- loss of large epidermal sheets without purpuric macules or target lesions

 Nikolsky Sign Positive
Distribution Acral – distal extremities Variable distribution Extensive distribution
Histo-pathology Interface dermatitis – Basal cell vacuolization, apoptotic bodies and inflammatory cells at Dermo-epidermal junction Dermo-epidermal separation, Intense inflammatory cell infiltrates in dermis, some areas of epidermal detachment  Epidermal necrosis, Dermo-epidermal separation, minimal dermal inflammatory cell infiltrate, large areas of epidermal detachment.
Recurrence Common, related to Herpes infections Uncommon, drug-related Uncommon, drug-related
Mortality Rare – recovery in 1 to 4 weeks Elevated mortality Highest mortality


 

Note: Overlap SJS-TEN: There is detachment of 10–30% body surface area, plus widespread purpuric macules or flat atypical targets.

Erythema Multiforme is regarded as a self‐limiting cytotoxic dermatitis resulting from cell‐mediated hypersensitivity most commonly to infection or drugs.

questions.text: 2. A middle-aged man comes with complaints of marked ptosis. Pupils are reactive on examination. You suspect it to be a case of isolated third nerve palsy. Which of the following conditions is known to commonly cause this presentation?
questions.solution:
One of the common causes of isolated third nerve palsy that presents with reactive pupils is diabetes mellitus. 

Diabetic oculomotor nerve palsy typically presents with ptosis and diplopia, and the pupillary function is often spared. The pupil is spared because diabetic microangiopathy involves the vasa nervorum. This causes ischemia of the nerve's main trunk ie. the inner fibers, and thus superficial pupillary fibers remain intact. Other microvascular diseases such as hypertension also commonly cause isolated third nerve palsy with reactive pupils. 

Other options:

Option A: Neuromyelitis optica is bilateral optic neuritis along with ascending myelitis, resulting in progressive quadriplegia. It is not associated with ocular palsies.

Option B: When posterior communicating artery aneurysm occurs at its junction with the internal carotid artery, it may lead to isolated third nerve palsy. The pupils are involved to an even greater extent than the extraocular muscles. This aneurysm compresses the blood vessels as well as the superficially located pupillary nerve fibers, thus affecting both functions. Aneurysms of the posterior communicating artery occurring at other locations will usually be assosciated with multiple cranial nerve palsies.

Option D: Subarachnoid hemorrhage may occur due to the sudden rupture of an aneurysm of the circle of Willis. It causes third nerve palsy and dilated pupils and is also associated with signs of meningeal irritation.

Pearl PM1982: Medullary syndromes and Weber syndrome

Syndrome

Vessel involved

Clinical features

Medial Medullary syndrome / Dejerine syndrome

Vertebral artery/Anterior spinal artery
  • C/L loss of conscious proprioception
  • C/L hemiplegia
  • I/L tongue paralysis

Lateral Medullary syndrome / Wallenberg syndrome

Vertebral artery>Posterior inferior cerebellar artery
  • C/L loss of pain/temperature on the body
  • I/L loss of pain/temperature on face
  • Ataxia
  • Nystagmus
  • Vertigo
  • Horner's syndrome
  • dysphagia
  • Ipsilateral bulbar paralysis
  • Loss of gag reflex

Weber's syndrome

Posterior cerebral artery
  • I/L Oculomotor nerve palsy - ptosis with fixed dilated pupil pointed down and out
  • C/L hemiplegia
  • C/L paralysis of the lower face


C/L- Contralateral

I/L-Ipsilateral

Pearl PM2228: Superior orbital fissure



Structures passing through the Superior orbital fissure

Above the common tendinous ring: LFT (Superolateral compartment)

* Lacrimal nerve

* Frontal nerve

* Trochlear nerve

* Superior ophthalmic vein

Within the common tendinous ring: BAN (Intermediate compartment)

* Both divisions of oculomotor nerve

* Abducens nerve

* Nasociliary nerve

Below the common tendinous ring (Inferomedial compartment)

* Inferior ophthalmic vein

questions.text:
3. A 34-year-old female patient presents with complaints of chronic cough, fatigue, joint pains, and swelling of both cheeks. She also complains of painful rashes on her knees which were diagnosed as erythema nodosum. On examination, the pulse rate is 90/min, respiratory rate is 19/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Her chest X-Ray is shown below. Which of the following is likely to be seen in this condition?

ACTH: Adrenocorticotropic hormone
questions.solution:
The clinical features, X-ray showing bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, together with the presence of erythema nodosum, suggests the diagnosis of sarcoidosis. Hypercalcemia is seen in patients with sarcoidosis. 

Sarcoidosis is a granulomatous disorder of unknown etiology that is characterized by the presence of non-caseating granulomas.

In acute cases, patients may typically present with Lofgren’s syndrome, consisting of arthritis, erythema nodosum, uveitis, bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, lethargy, and occasional fever. Patients may also present with insidious onset of cough, breathlessness, and radiographic infiltrates.

An image of erythema nodosum is shown below:



Investigations:

* Lymphopenia and deranged liver function tests are usually seen.

* Hypercalcemia is seen that is due to the increased synthesis of calcitriol (1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D) by the granuloma. In some patients, there may be hypercalciuria, which can lead to nephrocalcinosis.

* Pulmonary function test shows a restrictive lung disease, with impaired gas exchange.

* Bronchoscopy shows the typical 'cobblestone' appearance of the mucosa. Bronchial and transbronchial biopsies reveal non-caseating granulomas. An increased CD4:CD8 T-cell ratio may be seen in bronchoalveolar lavage.

* A chest X-ray is useful for staging sarcoidosis.

* HRCT shows reticulonodular opacities and peribronchial thickening that are predominant in the subpleural areas.

Below is an image of the chest X-ray (a) and coronal (a’) high-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) scans showing the typical symmetric reticulonodular opacities of sarcoidosis:



Note:

* Hypercalcemia and/or hypercalciuria occur in about 10% of sarcoidosis patients. It is more common in whites than in African Americans and in men.

* The mechanism of abnormal calcium metabolism is increased production of 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D by the granuloma itself.

* The 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D causes increased intestinal absorption of calcium, leading to hypercalcemia with a suppressed parathyroid hormone (PTH) level.

 Treatment options:

* Glucocorticoids remain the main drug of choice in the treatment of sarcoidosis.

* In those patients who require persistent corticosteroids, the following steroid-sparing alternatives are considered 

* Hydroxychloroquine 

* Methotrexate

* Azathioprine

* Leflunomide

* Mycophenolate

* Cyclophosphamide

* Thalidomide, to some extent, in a limited number of cases

Other options:

Option B- Although patients with chronic cough should be evaluated for tuberculosis, a tuberculin test is unlikely to be positive in this patient with typical features of sarcoidosis.

Option C- A stratosphere sign is seen on ultrasound in patients with pneumothorax. The image below shows the same.



Option D- Elevated ACTH is seen in patients with small cell carcinoma as a paraneoplastic syndrome leading to Cushingoid features.

questions.text: 4. A 65-year-old female with type 2 diabetes mellitus presented to the emergency department after a suicide attempt in which an unknown quantity of metformin was ingested. On biochemical examination, her lactate levels are raised. What is the type of lactic acidosis encountered here?
questions.solution:
Metformin (biguanide) toxicity encountered here is a Type B lactic acidosis.

Lactic acidosis is defined as an increase in plasma lactate levels. The various types of L-lactic acidosis are:

* Type A - This occurs secondary to poor tissue perfusion. The conditions include shock, cardiac failure, severe anemia, carbon monoxide, or cyanide toxicity.

* Type B - This type of lactic acidosis occurs in aerobic disorders. It can occur secondary to malignancies, renal failure, hepatic failure, drugs like metformin, ethanol, ethylene glycol, and methanol, diabetes mellitus, seizures, Severe malaria/ cholera, etc.

Note: D-lactic acidosis is an unusual form of metabolic acidosis that occurs in patients with short bowel syndrome, post-jejunoileal bypass, or intestinal obstruction. This is due to the formation of D-lactate by gut bacteria.

Pearl PM1521: Causes of Metabolic Acidosis

High Anion-Gap Metabolic Acidosis (MUDPILES) Normal Anion-Gap Metabolic Acidosis (FUSED CAR)
Methanol Fistula pancreatic
Uremia (Renal failure - Acute or Chronic) Ureterosigmoidostomy
Diabetic ketoacidosis Small bowel fistula
Paraldehyde Extra chloride (Hyperalimentation)
Iron tablets, INH Diarrhea
Lactic acidosis Carbonic anhydrase inhibitor (acetazolamide)
Ethylene glycol Addison's disease
Salicylates Renal tubular acidosis

questions.text: 5. Which of the following neuropsychological tests is used to measure fine finger dexterity?
questions.solution:
The grooved pegboard test is used to measure fine finger dexterity, motor speed, and hand-eye coordination.

In this test, the patient must put notched pegs into the appropriate slotted holes in a board. Below is an image of the grooved pegboard test.



Other options:

Option A: The Wisconsin Card Sorting Test (WCST) measures the problem-solving ability of a person. It requires a person to sort a long series of differently designed cards, which is to be done by incorporating feedback from an examiner.

Option C: Shipley Scale-II is a brief pen-and-paper measure of multiple choice vocabulary, open-ended verbal abstraction, and visual abstraction.

Option D: Rey-Osterreith Complex Figure Test is a visual-spatial assessment technique. It requires an individual to copy a highly complex geometrical configuration and then draw it from memory. It can be used on individuals 9 years and above.

Below is an example of a stimulus image used in this test.

questions.text: 6. A 54-year-old chronic alcoholic has been diagnosed with Korsakoffs psychosis. Which area of the brain is impacted during the chronic stages of his condition?
questions.solution:
In chronic cases of Korsakoff's psychosis, there will be atrophy of the mamillary bodies.

Periventricular lesions surrounding the third and fourth ventricles are generally seen in acute cases of thiamine deficiency, manifesting as Wernicke's encephalopathy. Untreated Wernicke's encephalopathy can lead to Korsakoff’s psychosis, which is a chronic manifestation of thiamine deficiency. The amnestic episodes seen in Korsakoff's psychosis are associated with lesions in the dorsal medial nuclei of the thalamus.

The typical features of this disease are anterograde amnesia with loss of recent memory in an alert and responsive patient. Patients with Korsakoff's syndrome also typically have a personality change, with a lack of initiative, reduced spontaneity, and a lack of interest.

Confabulation is a characteristic feature of Korsakoff's psychosis, which involves the unconscious filling of gaps in memory with inaccurate, fabricated, and often implausible information. The preceding thiamine deficiency has produced irreversible changes in the medial thalamic nuclei and mammillary bodies; hence, no specific treatment is available.

questions.text: 7. A patient complains of imbalance and blurry vision while walking. He was started on gentamicin 1 week ago. Head impulse test is abnormal in both directions and responses to caloric testing are reduced. Apart from discontinuing gentamicin which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
This is a case of gentamicin-induced bilateral vestibular hypofunction, and the appropriate management is vestibular rehabilitation.

Bilateral vestibular hypofunction (BVH) is most commonly caused by vestibulotoxic effects of aminoglycosides such as gentamicin. It is characterized by complaints of imbalance while walking (especially in the dark), blurry vision with head movement (oscillopsia), bilateral abnormal head impulse test, and reduced response to caloric testing. Patients typically do not have vertigo as vestibular function is lost on both sides, leading to no asymmetry of vestibular input. 

Clinical signs of vestibulotoxicity occur about a week after gentamicin administration. Bedside tests of vestibular function, such as assessment of dynamic visual acuity and head impulse test, should be performed daily to stop gentamicin if vestibulotoxicity occurs. 

Causes of BVH include : 

* Idiopathic

* Part of a neurodegenerative disorder

* Iatrogenic (medication ototoxicity)

* Other causes: degenerative diseases of the cerebellum, meningitis, systemic autoimmune diseases, trauma, bilateral Ménière disease, and bilateral vestibular schwannomas (neurofibromatosis type 2)

Examination findings of BVH include diminished dynamic visual acuity due to loss of stable vision when the head is moving, abnormal head impulse test in both directions, Romberg sign, and reduced responses to caloric testing. Apart from discontinuing the offending drug, current therapy for BVH is vestibular rehabilitation therapy. 

Vestibular rehabilitation therapy (VRT) is a specialized form of physical therapy designed to alleviate imbalance and dizziness associated with vestibular disorders. It involves a series of exercises that help to retrain the brain and vestibular system to compensate for any damage or dysfunction.

Other options : 

Option A: Vestibular suppressant medications such as meclizine and promethazine should not be used, as they will increase the imbalance. 

Option C: Vestibular implants hold future potential as a treatment, but are not currently indicated.

Option D: The patient's condition may gradually improve by observation alone, but vestibular rehabilitation therapy helps improve symptoms.

questions.text: 8. Which of the following ocular sign seen in allergic rhinitis is called allergic shiners?
questions.solution:
The dark circles seen under the eyes are called allergic shiners.

Other ocular findings seen in allergic rhinitis include marked conjunctival congestion with a characteristic “cobblestone” appearance due to hypertrophied papillae, along with eyelid edema, periorbital puffiness, and intense itching or tearing.

A finding similar to allergic shiners called allergic salute is seen as a black line across the middle of the dorsum of the nose due to constant upward rubbing of the nose, simulating a salute.

questions.text: 9. A 62-year-old woman who has been complaining of unilateral headache and jaw pain for 2 weeks, now comes with complaints of blurry vision. She also has a history of stiffness and pain in her shoulders and hips. Visual field examination shows a pale optic disc. Which of the following is the most probable pathophysiology seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical picture is suggestive of giant cell arteritis (GCA) with polymyalgia rheumatica, which is most commonly associated with anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AION).

AION is due to the interference in the circulation of the posterior ciliary artery supplying the anterior part of the optic nerve. Anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AION) can be classified into two types, as follows:

* Arteritic AION: caused by giant-cell arteritis

* Non-arteritic AION (NAAION): most common

Clinical features:

Features

AAION

NAAION

Age

>60 years

<60 years

Sex

F > M

F = M

Headache

Jaw claudication

Present

Absent

Visual loss

Marked

Less marked

Optic disc

Pale disc edema

Hyperemic disc edema with flame-shaped hemorrhages

C-reactive proteins

Raised

Normal

ESR

Highly raised

(> 40 mm in the first hour)

Raised

(20 - 40 mm in the first hour)

Fluorescein angiogram

Disc and

choroidal filling delay

Only disc delay

Treatment

Corticosteroids

Levodopa–carbidopa combination for 3 weeks and then double dose for 1 month


The image given below shows pale chalky white optic disc edema of arteritic AION.



In GCA with visual changes, corticosteroid therapy should be started as soon as possible. An intravenous loading dose of 200 mg hydrocortisone or 500 mg methylprednisolone administered slowly over one hour is recommended. It is followed by high doses of oral prednisolone (1 mg/kg/day) given daily for the first week. A maintenance dose of 5–15 mg is continued for at least 6–12 months.

Other Options: 

Option A: Central retinal artery occlusion presents as a sudden painless loss of vision. It is most often caused due to an embolus from an atherosclerotic plaque. Fundus examination shows an opaque, milky-white retina with a cherry-red spot, as shown below.



Option C: Central retinal vein occlusion also causes painless loss of vision, although not as rapidly as CRAO. Fundoscopy demonstrates tortuous engorged veins and retinal hemorrhages as shown below.



Option D: Posterior ischemic optic neuropathy involves the small pial vessels supplying the intraorbital portion of the optic nerve. Although it is associated with vasculitides like giant cell arteritis and systemic lupus erythematosus, it doesn't affect the fundus. There is no edema or hemorrhage on fundoscopy.

The image below shows a normal fundus in posterior ischemic optic neuropathy.

questions.text:
10. Match the following skull radiology findings and the associated conditions.

1) Salt and pepper appearance A) Hurler's syndrome
2) J-shaped sella B) Paget's disease
3) Punched-out lesions C) Hyperparathyroidism
4) Cotton wool appearance D) Multiple myeloma
questions.solution:
The correct option is 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, 4-B.

* Salt and pepper appearance - Hyperparathyroidism 

* J-shaped sella - Hurler's syndrome

* Punched-out lesions - Multiple myeloma

* Cotton wool appearance - Paget's disease

Salt and pepper appearance of the skull: It is also known as pepper pot skull and is seen in hyperparathyroidism. It is characterized by multiple tiny well-defined lucencies in the skull that occur due to resorption of the trabecular bone.

Other radiological findings in hyperparathyroidism:

* Sub-periosteal resorption - Classical and pathognomonic feature of hyperparathyroidism

* Loss of lamina dura 

* Expansile lytic lesion, otherwise known as brown tumor, generally affecting maxilla/ mandible

Image showing salt and pepper appearance of the skull:



J-shaped sella - It is a skull radiographic finding in Hurler's syndrome.

Other radiological findings in Hurler's syndrome:

* Macrocephaly

* Thickened calvaria (skull cap)

* Oar-shaped ribs

* Hook-shaped vertebral bodies

Note: J-shaped sella can also be seen in other conditions like optic chiasm glioma, hydrocephalus, neurofibromatosis, as a normal anatomic variant, etc.

Image showing J-shaped sella:



Punched-out lesions - It is frequently associated with multiple myeloma. 

Other important causes for punched-out skull lesions include metastatic lesions, tuberculosis, sarcoidosis, epidermoid tumor, fibrous dysplasia, etc.

Image showing punched-out lesions of the skull:



Cotton wool appearance - It is seen in Paget's disease of the bone. It refers to the mixed lytic and sclerotic lesions of the skull.

Other skull radiological findings in Paget's disease:

* Osteoporosis circumscripta - Large, well-defined lytic lesions involving the inner part of the outer table of the skull with an intact inner table

* Diploic widening

* Tam o' Shanter sign

questions.text: 11. A 28-year-old man with gluten sensitivity presents with severely itchy papulovesicular lesions on extremities, knees, elbows, and buttocks for one year with histopathology showing subepidermal blister. Direct immunofluorescence staining of these lesions would reveal ________
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image is suggestive of Dermatitis herpetiformis and direct immunofluorescence staining of the lesion would show Granular IgA deposition in the papillary dermis.

Image showing multiple grouped papulovesicular lesions on extensor aspects associated with history of severe itching and sub-epidermal blisters on histopathology in a patient with gluten sensitivity are specific clues that point towards the diagnosis of Dermatitis herpetiformis. 

Dermatitis herpetiformis, also known as Duhring’s disease, is an autoimmune disease associated with HLA DQ-2 and HLA DQ-8. The antibodies target epidermal transglutaminase-3, resulting in the collection of neutrophils at the dermal papilla. This condition is closely associated with Celiac disease (Gluten-sensitive enteropathy). 

The clinical manifestations include grouped vesicles and papules. These lesions are commonly located over the extensor aspects of knees, elbows, buttocks, back, and scalp with symmetrical distribution and are associated with intense pruritus. 

The characteristic histopathology finding is subepidermal blisters with papillary tip microabscesses containing neutrophils, which is shown in the image below:



Pearl PM0224: Vesiculobullous Disorders

Disease Clinical Manifestations Histology Immuno-pathology Autoantigens
Pemphigus vulgaris       Flaccid blisters, denuded skin,oro-mucosal lesions Acantholytic blister formed in suprabasal layer of epidermis  Cell surface deposits of IgG on keratinocytes- fish net pattern Dsg3, Dsg1 in patients with skin involvement
Pemphigus foliaceus       Crusts and shallow erosions on the scalp, central face, upper chest, and back Acantholytic blister formed in superficial layer of epidermis  Cell surface deposits of IgG onkeratinocytes Dsg1
Bullous pemphigoid     Large tense blisters on flexor surfaces and trunk  Subepidermal blister with eosinophil-rich infiltrate Linear band of IgG and/or C3 in epidermal BMZ  BPAG1, BPAG2
Dermatitis herpetiformis      Extremely pruritic small papules and vesicles on elbows, knees, buttocks, and posterior neck Subepidermal blister with neutrophils in dermal papillae  Granular deposits of IgA at the tips of dermal papillae Epidermal trans-glutaminase
Linear IgA disease     Pruritic small papules on extensor surfaces; occasionally larger, arciform blisters  Subepidermal blister with neutrophil-rich infiltrate  Linear band of IgA in epidermalBMZ BPAG2
Epidermo-lysis bullosa acquisita Tense bullae and erosions  Subepidermal blister  IgG and C3 DEJ – Continous and linear  Type VII collagen


 The images below shows clinical pictures of pemphigus patients.

* Image A - oral erosions in a patient with pemphigus vulgaris

* Image B - heavily clotted and crusted lesions around the mouth in a patient with paraneoplastic pemphigus

* Image C - skin lesions found on the trunk in a patient with pemphigus vulgaris

* Image D - skin lesions on the trunk in a patient with pemphigus foliaceus

questions.text: 12. Which of the following radiological imaging modalities are used to examine the fibres seen in the structure marked below?
questions.solution:
The marked structure in the given image of the sagittal section of the brain is the corpus callosum, which contains white matter fibres called commissural fibres. The technique used to map white matter fibres is called diffusion tensor imaging (DTI).

Diffusion tensor imaging is a variation of diffusion-weighted imaging, where the diffusion of the fluid is assessed in six or more directions. It helps to identify the location, orientation, and anisotropy of the white matter tracts and their connections (tractography). It is used in preoperative planning to visualize the relations between intrinsic brain tumours and surrounding neural connections and identify any disease process that affects them.

White matter fibres include:

* Association fibres

* Commissural fibres

* Projection fibres

* Subcortical fibres.

The technique is based on the principle that the diffusion in the brain is directionally dependent (anisotropic), which is more evident in the compacted white matter tracts, and least evident in the grey matter. 

The image below shows diffusion tensor tractography:



AF-Arcuate fasciculus, SLF- Superior longitudinal fasciculus , ILF- Inferior longitudinal fasciculus , UF-Uncinate fasciculus , IFOF-Inferior fronto-occipital fasciculus . (Arrows at bottom right. A: Anterior, L: Lateral).

Commissural fibres originate in one hemisphere, cross the midline, and project to the contralateral hemisphere.

The locations of the commissural fibres are as follows:

* Corpus callosum- Medial surface of the brain

* Anterior commissure- Beneath the rostrum of the corpus callosum

* Posterior commissure- In the inferior lamina of the pineal gland

* Habenular commissure- In the superior lamina of the pineal gland

* Hippocampal commissure- Between the right fornix and the left fornix



Other options:

Option A: Dynamic contrast-enhanced MRI refers to the serial MRI acquisitions following the intravenous contrast agent.

Option B: Dynamic susceptibility contrast MRI measures induced alterations in the transverse relaxation times (T2 and T2*). This results in signal loss, causing transient darkening of the tissues.

Option D: Functional magnetic resonance imaging detects changes in the regional cerebral blood flow during various brain activities. It is used to study the eloquent (e.g., motor) cortical activation.

Pearl PM2240: White matter tracts of the brain

Commissural fibers: connect corresponding regions of two hemispheres.

They include

* Corpus callosum

* Anterior and posterior commissure

* Habenular commissure

* Hippocampal commissure of fornix

Association fibers: connect various cortical regions within the same hemisphere.

They are classified as 

* Short association fibers: lie immediately under the cortex and connect adjacent gyri. Eg- arcuate fasciculus

* Long association fibers:

* Uncinate fasciculus

* Cingulum

* Superior longitudinal fasciculus

* Inferior longitudinal fasciculus

* Fronto-occipital fasciculus

* Fornix (except hippocampal commissure of fornix)



Projection fibers: fibers passing to and from the brainstem to the cerebral cortex. 

* Internal capsule

* Corona radiata

questions.text: 13. Within 24 hours of induction of spinal anesthesia, a patient develops bilateral pain in the buttocks, radiating to the legs. This pain lasts less than a week. Which of the following drugs has the highest likelihood of causing such symptoms?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes transient neurological symptoms. Transient neurological symptoms (TNS) have the highest incidence with lidocaine.

TNS was previously known as transient radicular irritation. It is mostly attributed to the use of intrathecal lidocaine and mepivacaine. It is most common in patients who were placed in a lithotomy position during surgery.

Symptoms occur within 48 hours of the resolution of the spinal anesthetic. It presents as unilateral or bilateral pain in the buttocks that radiates to the legs. 

It is not related to the concentration of lidocaine, the addition of dextrose or epinephrine or solution osmolarity. Its incidence is decreased by the use of a double-orifice needle since single-orifice needles can increase the risk of injecting the anesthetic caudally in the thecal sac.

This condition is usually self-limiting. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs can be given. Some patients may require opioids.

questions.text: 14. A 55-year-old man complains of persistently aching legs. He also complained of hearing loss. However, his blood tests reveal an elevated serum alkaline phosphatase. An X-ray of the skull is given below. Which of the following malignancies is a complication of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a radiograph showing a cotton-wool skull is suggestive of Paget's disease of bone. Osteosarcoma is a malignant complication of this condition.

Paget's disease is characterized by focal areas of increased bone remodelling, resulting in the overgrowth of poorly organized bone. This unbalanced process leads to osseous deformities, nerve compressions, and pathological fractures. Paget's disease is usually seen at age >50 years. They are mostly asymptomatic but can present with a dull ache. Deformities are usually seen in the lower limbs, such as bowing of the tibia or femur. They may have deformities such as bowing of bones. The tibia bends anteriorly, and the femur bends anterolateral. If the skull is affected, enlargement of the skull is seen. 

Disorganized and increased bone deposition may lead to stenosis of various canals and foramina, resulting in compression of cranial nerves, spinal cord, and nerve roots (due to spinal stenosis). Hearing loss is a fairly common feature, due to compression of the cranial nerve and otosclerosis, resulting in mixed sensorineural and conductive hearing loss. Pathological fractures of the long bones may be seen. 

Serum calcium and phosphate are usually normal. Serum alkaline phosphatase is elevated.

The X-ray findings are characteristic and appear in stages.

* Osteolytic phase - It involves prominent bone resorption and marked hypervascularization. Radiographically, this manifests as an advancing lytic wedge on the shaft of the bone, or blade of grass, or flame-shaped lesion.

* Sclerotic phase - Bone resorption declines progressively and leads to a thick, less vascular pagetic or mosaic bone (coarse trabeculations)

Some of the radiographical signs include:

* Flame-shaped lesions- Seen in long bones due to localized osteolysis/osteopenia. 

* Picture-frame appearance manifests with cortical thickening and sclerosis encasing the vertebral margins.

* The ivory vertebra sign may be seen due to a diffuse and homogeneous increase in opacity of a vertebral body.

* Osteogenesis circumscripta describes circumscribed patches of radiolucency due to osteoporosis in the skull.

The arrow mark in the following image indicates a "blade of grass/flame-shaped lesion" appearance.



The image given below depicts the Ivory vertebra sign.



Below is an image depicting the picture-frame appearance seen in vertebral bodies.



Treatment:

Medical management includes bisphosphonates; IV Zolendronate is preferred. Surgical correction is done in cases of deformities and pathological fractures.

Complications:

* Risk of fractures due to decreased strength of bone 

* Osteoarthritis

* Bony overgrowth leads to spinal stenosis and nerve compression

* High-output cardiac failure due to the increased blood flow to skeletal bones

* Hypercalcemia may be seen in prolonged immobilization

* Cranial nerve-2nd, 5th, 7th, 8th palsy is seen

* Deafness due to nerve compression or otosclerosis

* Malignant transformation to osteosarcoma

questions.text: 15. A 24-year-old man is being evaluated for organ donation after being declared brain dead. Which of the following reflexes can be elicited even after brain death?
questions.solution:
The knee-jerk reflex can be elicited even after brain death.

Peripheral reflexes may be present in patients after brainstem death, as these reflex arcs don't depend on input from the brainstem.

In brain-dead patients, several phenomena may still be observed that should not be interpreted as evidence of brainstem function. These include spontaneous movements of the limbs, respiratory-like movements causing intercostal expansion, autonomic signs such as sweating, flushing, or tachycardia, and normal or transient increases in blood pressure. Reflexes, including deep tendon reflexes, superficial abdominal reflexes, and the Babinski sign, may also persist despite complete loss of brainstem activity.

The cardinal features of brain death include:

* Unresponsiveness or coma

* Apnea- impaired brainstem activity indicates damage to the medullary cardio-respiratory centers. This manifests as a loss of centrally controlled breathing

* Absence of brainstem reflexes:

* Cranial nerve II, III (optic and oculomotor)- absent direct and consensual light reflex. This is associated with dilated pupils measuring about 9 mm. 

* Cranial nerve VIII (vestibulocochlear)- absent oculocephalic (Doll's eye phenomenon) and oculovestibular (unresponsive to caloric testing) reflexes.

* Cranial nerve V, VII (trigeminal and facial)- absent corneal and jaw reflexes.

* Cranial nerve IX, X (glossopharyngeal and vagus)- absent cough and gag reflexes.

questions.text: 16. A 27-year-old woman with multiple sclerosis notes experiencing double vision. On examination, her eye movements are normal except for her right gaze where her left eye fails to adduct and her right eye shows nystagmus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of MS and above mentioned examination likely has a lesion in her left medial longitudinal fasciculus, causing a left-sided internuclear ophthalmoplegia.

INO is on the side that fails to adduct on contralateral gaze, i.e., the left eye fails to adduct when looking to the right.

A left-sided INO is a lesion in the left medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF). The left MLF sends conjugate signals from the (contralateral) right abducens interneurons to the (ipsilateral) left medial rectus motor neurons to adduct the left eye during the right(contralateral) gaze.

The left eye has weakness of adduction. Hence, the abducting right eye demonstrates a dissociated horizontal nystagmus as a compensatory response to overcome this weakness. This is because increased innervation to the medial rectus muscle also results in increased innervation to the contralateral lateral rectus, as these are yoke muscles (Hering’s law of equal innervation). This mechanism results in nystagmus.

Internuclear ophthalmoplegia, usually bilateral, is associated with multiple sclerosis.

questions.text: 17. A 60-year-old man who underwent abdominal surgery under general anesthesia developed lung atelectasis. Reduction in which of the following parameters is primarily responsible for this patient's respiratory failure?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of perioperative lung atelectasis is indicative of type III respiratory failure. This is caused by decreased functional residual capacity due to the effects of general anesthesia.

Following general anesthesia, functional residual capacity (FRC) decreases as a result of reduced muscular tone. FRC refers to the volume of air remaining in the lungs after a normal tidal expiration, representing the equilibrium point between lung and chest wall recoil forces. A reduction in FRC promotes airway closure and collapse of dependent lung regions, leading to atelectasis.

Management involves frequent repositioning, chest physiotherapy, maintaining an upright posture, and ensuring adequate pain control. Additionally, noninvasive positive-pressure ventilation can be employed to reverse regional atelectasis.

Forced expiratory volume (FEV) is a measure of the volume of air forcibly exhaled in one second during a pulmonary function test. While reduced FEV may indicate airway obstruction in conditions like chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), it is not the primary parameter responsible for type III respiratory failure.

Pearl PM1863: Types of Respiratory Failure

 

Type Name Mechanism Associated conditions
I Acute hypoxemic respiratory failure

Alveolar flooding and subsequent intrapulmonary shunt physiology.

Low pO2

Normal/ low pCO2

Sepsis

Gastric aspiration

Pneumonia

Near-drowning

Multiple blood transfusions

Pancreatitis
II

Hypoxemia with hypercapnia

Results from the inability to eliminate carbon dioxide effectively.

Low pO2

High pCO2

Normal (pAO2-paO2)

Drug overdose

Brainstem injury

Sleep-disordered breathing

Severe hypothyroidism

Myasthenia gravis

Guillain-Barre syndrome

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis
III Peri-operative respiratory failure Results from lung atelectasis. After general anesthesia.
IV Shock Results from hypoperfusion of respiratory muscles in patients with shock Cardiogenic shock.


 

pO2- partial pressure of oxygen

pCO2- partial pressure of carbon dioxide

(pAO2-paO2)- alveolar- arterial oxygen gradient

Pearl PM1010: Lung volumes and capacities

Measurement

Description

Normal Value

Tidal volume (TV)

The amount of air that moves into the lungs with each inspiration (or the amount that moves out with each expiration) during quiet breathing

500–750 mL.

Inspiratory reserve volume (IRV)

The air inspired with a maximal inspiratory effort in excess of the TV

∼3 L

Expiratory reserve volume (ERV)

The volume expelled by an active expiratory effort after passive expiration

∼1.1 L

Residual volume (RV)

The air left in the lungs after a maximal expiratory effort

∼1.2 L

Total lung capacity (TLC)

IRV+TV+ERV+RV

∼5.8 L

Vital capacity (VC)

IRV+TV+ERV

∼4.5 L

Inspiratory capacity (IC)

TV+IRV

∼3.5 L

Expiratory capacity (EC)

TV+ERV

∼1.6 L

Functional residual capacity (FRC)

ERV+RV

∼2.3 L

questions.text: 18. Weakness of which of the following muscles gives rise to the given appearance of glottis in a case of phonasthenia ?
questions.solution:
The image shows a triangular space, which is seen in phonasthenia, when the inter-arytenoid muscles alone are involved.

Phonasthenia is the weakness of voice due to fatigue of the laryngeal muscles. This leads to a gap between the vocal cords that can be visualized on indirect laryngoscopy. The shape of the gap depends on the muscles involved:

* Thyroarytenoid alone: elliptical space

* Interarytenoid alone: triangular space

* Both thyroarytenoid & inter arytenoid: Keyhole appearance

This condition is treated with voice rest, especially after excessive use of voice and vocal hygiene.

Spasms of the posterior cricoarytenoid muscle cause abductor dysphonia.



Pearl PM1978: Muscles of larynx

Remember 2 exceptions:

* All muscles are adductors, except PCA (an abductor)

* All muscles are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve, except cricothyroid (superior laryngeal nerve)

Action
Muscle
Opening of the inlet of larynx
Thyroepiglotticus
Closing of the inlet of larynx
Aryepiglotticus, Interarytenoids
Abductor of vocal cords
Posterior cricoarytenoid
Adductor of vocal cords
Lateral cricoarytenoid
Tensor of vocal cords
Cricothyroid
Relaxer of vocal cord
Thyroarytenoid
Modulator of larynx
Vocalis


Safety muscle of larynx: Posterior cricoarytenoid

Safety muscle of tongue: Genioglossus

The muscle of whispering: Lateral cricoarytenoid

Vocalis is known as the modulator of larynx because, the anterior part of the vocalis muscle can tense the vocal cord, and its posterior part can relax the vocal cord.

questions.text: 19. A child is brought with malodorous scalp lesions as shown below. Wood's lamp examination of hair follicles reveals blue-grey fluorescence. What is the causative organism responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The above image shows cup‐shaped scutula (crusts) around hair follicles, which is suggestive of favus. It is a manifestation of tinea capitis, an inflammatory infection of the hair follicle caused by Trichophyton schoenleinii.

Favus is a chronic fungal infection in which dense yellow crusts (scutula) develop in the hair follicles with a distinct malodorous smell, leading to scarring alopecia. T. schoenleinii is the most common cause. T. violaceum and Microsporum gypseum are rare causes but have been reported. 

T. schoenleinii demonstrates blue-gray fluorescence on Wood lamp examination. Microscopy with KOH preparation reveals hyphae arranged lengthwise around and within the hair shaft with rare arthroconidia.

Tinea capitis is of four types: 

Type of Infection Causative fungus 
Endothrix (infection inside shaft)
  • Trichophyton tonsurans
  • T. violaceum
  • T. schoenleinii
  • T. yaoundei
  • T. soudanense
Ectothrix (infection outside shaft)
  • Microsporum audouinii
  • M.canis
  • M.equinum
  • M.ferrugineum
Favus
  • T. schoenleinii
Kerion
  • T. verrucosum
  • T. mentagrophytes


Other options:

Option B: T. tonsurans is a cause of tinea capitis, most commonly causing endothrix pattern of infection. It does not display fluorescence under Wood's lamp.

Option C: T. violaceum is a rare cause of favus, although it does not display fluorescence under Wood's lamp.

Option D: T. verrucosum is a common cause of kerion, which is a severe inflammatory type of tinea capitis that presents with an inflammatory mass with thick crusting and matting of hair with pus and sinus formation.

Pearl PM0260: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

Table: Various diseases and their color on Wood’s lamp examination

Disease

Colour on Wood’s Light

Tinea capitis

 

Microsporum species: brilliant green (M. canis, M. audouinii, M. ferrugineum, M. distortum)

Trichophyton schoenleinii: pale green

Most Trichophyton species, with the exception of T. schoenleinii, are non-fluorescent

Erythrasma

Coral pink

Pityriasis versicolor

Faint yellow

Pseudomonas

Green

Scabies

Fluorescein solution fills the burrows and fluoresces on Wood’s light.

Porphyria

Urine, feces, blister fluid fluoresce red or pink

Vitiligo

Ivory or milky white

questions.text: 20. The most common cause of neuropathic (Charcot’s) joint is ________
questions.solution:
Diabetes mellitus is the most common cause of Charcot's joint (arthropathy).

Charcot's arthropathy is a neurodegenerative process that threatens both the function and viability of the limb. It progresses through the phases of bony destruction, resorption, and deformity.

Other causes include

* Syphilis

* Heavy metal poisoning

* Alcoholic or congenital neuropathy

* Leprosy

* Rheumatoid arthritis

* Idiopathic
